Award.AwardTitle: Developing a Practice-based Interdisciplinary Teacher Preparation Program at the Intersection of Science, Second Language, and Literacy Acquisition
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to serve the national interest in high quality STEM education. To this end, it plans to improve curricula in a secondary science teacher education program. In addition to the consistently low performance of U.S. secondary students on international tests, a significant and consistent national gap exists in the science achievement of English learners versus native English-speaking students. One-third of all English learners in the U.S. are in secondary school settings. However, most secondary preservice teacher education programs do not include an explicit English learner focus in science methods courses. As a result, many teachers lack experience and coursework in the language and literacy demands of teaching science to English learners. This project proposes to focus on scientific inquiry, second language learning, and science-specific literacy to better prepare secondary (Grades 6-12) and preservice teachers to teach science to all students, including English learners. A successful new curriculum created through this project could be adapted by other science teacher preparation programs. Expected outcomes of the project include an increase in new teachers’ lesson planning and teaching skills using approaches that: 1) Engage students in science and engineering practices; 2) Implement skills and strategies for scaffolding the learning of English learners; 3) Integrate science-specific literacy.

Teacher educators at the University of Central Florida aim to create a practice-based, interdisciplinary program that targets preservice teacher preparation over four undergraduate courses during two semesters. These courses will include two courses at the University and two internship courses in the local school district, the Seminole County Public Schools. Pre-service teachers will be engaged in a series of practices including focused inquiry, directed observations, and guided practice to learn how to teach science to all students. Mixed methods research will be used to explore research questions that include the impact on teacher’s lesson planning and teaching skills and learning outcomes of students who are taught by these new teachers. The pre-service teachers’ performance will be compared with those who graduated from the University’s secondary science education programs before implementing this programmatic transformation. The teaching effectiveness of pre-service teachers will also be measured by comparing the learning outcomes of their students in the internship classrooms with those in the control group. Specific practices and conditions of the project that lead to improvements in the pre-service teachers’ skills will also be explored. An ongoing project evaluation will be conducted throughout the three project years. The evaluation will engage all stakeholders in the assessment cycle to provide feedback and inform the research team about progress toward the objectives and potential improvements to the project design. Dissemination activities will include a project website, peer-reviewed publications, and national and international conference presentations. The resulting curriculum will be shared with practitioner audiences, including science teachers in secondary science classrooms and science methods course instructors in diverse undergraduate teacher education programs across the nation. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research Question 1. Are there any statistically significant differences in the ISSLA preservice teachers’ (PSTs)’ lesson planning and teaching skills before Internship I, during Internship I, Internship II, and during the first semester teaching post-graduation? If yes, what are the differences?

There is a statistically significant difference between the posttest and pretest scores of lesson plans that are rated using a trifocal rubric. First, Wilcoxon Singed Ranks tests were conducted to compare the pair of the differences between the posttest and pretest total scores. The test results revealed that there is statistically significant difference between the ranks of the total scores for pretest and posttest with Z= -3.064 and p = .002. When we examined the scores, we found the mean rank differences with the posttest of 19.20 points higher than the pretest.

Second, Wilcoxon Singed Ranks tests revealed the statistically significant differences between the posttest and pretest scores in five pairs, namely Relevance and Authenticity, Building Progressions, Scientific accuracy, Student Ideas, and Evaluation except Differentiated Instruction.

Third, Wilcoxon Singed Ranks tests revealed the statistically significant differences between the posttest and pretest scores in Science, Literacy, and EL support pretest scores with p = .002, p = .006, and p = .002respectively.  The descriptive statistics showed that the PSTs had systematically higher raw scores of posttests than their pretests in all three areas

Research Question 2. Are there any statistically significant differences in lesson planning and teaching skills between the PSTs who participate the ISSLLA program and those who do not? If yes, what are the differences?

In general, students taught by PSTs that were in ISSLLA performed higher than the students taught by the PSTs in control group. There are statistically significant group differences between the treatment and control group in the gain scores with F (3, 552) = 13.842, p < .001, and η2= .06 with the higher mean of gain scores of the treatment group (M=4.83, SD = 9.35) than the control group means of gain scores (M=3.75, SD=6.33) on science achievement.

Research Question 3. Are there any statistically significant differences in science learning outcomes between the public school students taught by the PSTs who attend the ISSLLA program and those taught by non-ISSLLA PSTs depending on student demographic groups (e.g., gender and EL status)? If yes, what are the group differences?

Although ELs taught by the PSTs in ISSLLA program performed lower that non-ELs in the same group, ELs taught by PSTs in the treatment group performed higher than ELs taught by the PSTs in the control group. The analysis results reveal the marginal treatment effect on ELs’ science learning, with F (3, 552) = 2.504, p = .058, and η2 = .13. Specifically, the treatment group had higher mean gain scores (M=4.64, SD=5.88) than the control group (M=2.10, SD=6.57).

Research Question 4. How does the ISSLLA program impact the PSTs’ lesson planning and teaching skills?

1. Findings from the end-of-program survey and brief self-reflection last course sessions showed that the PSTs positively perceived their experiences using TeachLivE™, the simulation classroom, to improve their pedagogical skills of working with multilingual students. The PSTs appreciated how TeachLivE™ exposed them to different levels of multilingual learners.

2. At the end of program, PSTs reported that observing their peers was helpful to their learning.

For example, Phoebe (Chemistry), end-of-semester survey: “I feel like seeing my peers made me feel less alone, but I also got tons of fresh new ideas to use and have actually implemented some [in my classroom] already.” Paired with her TeachLivE™ self-reflection: “… I also liked Rachel’s lesson with [her hand gestures] … I was like yes [her hand gestures] make sense and I think doing motions [would be helpful to the multilingual learners] because I talk with my hands.” and Julie (Earth Science), end-of-semester survey: “… After watching all my peers complete the TeachLivE activity and [receive] feedback from Dr. Nutta and Dr. Zygouris-Coe, I know how to prepare for [multilingual learners] and planning activities and providing them with tools around their ability levels.

3. All PSTs expressed their appreciation for the interdisciplinary feedback provided by the research team composed of three teacher educators in science, disciplinary literacy, and TESOL content areas.

The results of this research initiative informs solutions to the challenges of educating ELs in science classrooms, especially at the secondary level where the research literature is limited. The primary direct outcomes of the project are 20 PSTs and 400 public school students in secondary science classrooms.  By participating in this research, PSTs have been better prepared to teach science to their future students, including ELs.
